name: Rw005g
comment info:
The article does not look at all the consequences of increasing elderly populations in the West. Food Production in the US will dramatically start to decrease within the next few decades, due to labor shortages. Relying wholly on mechanization or immigrant labor will not be sufficient and we will not be able to meet the food demands of the developing world. The population growth rates of some in the developing world, are linked to access to Western grain and corn imports. If and when these decrease, there will be massive famine in Africa. It's attenuated and counter-intuitive, but it will happen.

Africa will have a huge population of younger working-age population. But they will not be able to reap any of the benefits of this, because food imports, medical aid imports, all these things that Africa needs from more advanced nations will be pulled back and decreased, as these older nations go into a cocoon-like state of demographic hibernation. Africa may suffer greatly when this happens. Or, perhaps, they will immigrate to a de-populated Europe and America and find sparsely populated vacant cities, farming fields, and abandoned industrial plants---all just waiting for people to man the levers of production.

name: Tom Callahan
comment info:
As a Professional Data Consultant in 1995, I first bumped into the Baby Boom in a particual school district's data. I found that the early Boomers (1947-1956) became teachers in masses around 1966 as they entered collage. In 1995, after the typical 30 year carrer they began retireing in masses. This effect is occuring again now, with the second wave of generation X teachers.  
Now I am retired and writting a book, titled Echo, the effects of the Baby Boom.  And its not pretty.  I believe population data in the US is flawed.  I believe we are about to experience somthing like never before, where the replacement rate is so low, and the older boomers are about to die in an upward spike (as they were born) causing massive upheavals.  In 1995, I went down this rabbit hole of what if's.  Image a day, soon, where a business has requires 100 workers, and on that day 4 retire, and only one is available to hire. And the next day, 8 retire, and only one is again, availble to hire. By the third day, the business must shut down.  Schools in the Northeast USA are shutting down for lack of teachers AND students. Because the birth rate dropped since 1975, the US population is simply getting older. At 40%, its pure chaos 
We MAY be able to predict effects based on other old age population countries, but the information may be too late.
AI may solve the problem, but unitl the problem manifest itself, business may be reluctant in invest.  

I would love to communicate with regarding this topic.

name: Wade Marolf
comment info:
This graph is especially interesting to me - I've been fascinated with population dispersion for a little while, and seeing it in a graph with a comparison to the past and a prediction for the future is incredible. 

I notice that a majority of the population as of now is centralized in India and China, and both areas - "hotspots" if you will - are marked to be of working age.

Compared to 1990, the populations are largely changed; India's population reached an average of the working age, and both area's populations expanded dramatically. Now, compared to the predictions for the future, I'm amazed.

I interpret the predictive graph of 2050 as such: India's population expands impressively, and the general populous remains of working age. China experiences a decreased population, and the national average features older populations. There's a population boom in most areas of central and southern Africa, and most of Europe becomes older generations. North America and South America remain largely unchanged - aside from the aging of their population. 

I wonder, after writing this, how accurately the world will follow the prediction. In addition, I'm curious what might cause the world to deviate from the prediction. What sort of global tragedies, such as wars or more pandemics, might change the population or age distribution of the world? How might the United States struggle through this, and how might my small town be harmed or helped by it?

"A Growing World - What We Expect"

name: Katherine H
comment info:
This illustrates the average age range of countries, or regions, all over the globe. The graph's most interesting is how many countries fall into the younger population (15 and under). While countries such as India and France are seen to be changing in average age range, that is the majority of their society increasing in age, countries in Africa and the Middle East, such as Nigeria, continuously stay in younger population range. With a younger population constantly being the majority, what is more prevalent, is short life spans or mothers constantly giving birth? As for China,  the older age range (65 and above) will dominate by 2050. This is a direct result of their 1 child rule in families. This multi-children ban was an attempt to combat the issue of overpopulation. However, it was proven to not only be worrisome in communities, as people were killing and or abandoning their kids, but leading directly to the problem depicted on the graph. With an older population taking over, how will this affect the economy? Who will take over the jobs that 65-year-olds are unable to do? If this starts affecting China in a negative way, when will it start to affect the world as a whole? As for my own community, the only issue I feel that will affect it is the issue of China. The graph shows that even though the US population is getting older, the national age average seems to dip back and forth.

“Older, Younger, Or Just Right? What Dominating Age Will Take Over Populations By 2050?”

name: Ella Hindmarsh
comment info:
I noticed a significant shift in global age distribution. Developed nations, such as the U.S., Europe, and East Asia, have increasingly aging populations from 1990 to 2050, as indicated by the colors transitioning from green to orange on the graph. In contrast, regions like Africa and parts of Latin America maintain predominantly younger populations, reflected in the consistent blue coloring. This transformation might be attributed to the ongoing development and modernization of these countries.

I wonder what is causing the population to get older? Is it due to declining birth rates? Increased life expectancy? Lower immigration? Urbanization?

This affects my community as an aging population can strain healthcare, affect the labor force, and stress pension systems in your community. It may require adjustments in housing, social services, and urban planning. Encouraging intergenerational interactions and seizing economic opportunities are crucial for a well-balanced and thriving community.

Catchy headlines: From Cradle to Canes: The Global Agequake Chronicles

The Silver Storm: Unmasking the Ageing Phenomenon

Youth Fades, Wisdom Stays: A World in Transition

Chronicles of Aging Nations: The Quiet Revolution

From Baby Boom to Silver Surge: Global Agequake Ahead

The Graying Globe: A Demographic Tug-of-War

replies.comment info:
@Ella Hindmarsh 
This is such a well-thought out response. You have a lot of interesting thoughts about the implications of these shifting demographics. I particularly enjoyed your headlines! I am going to include one of them in the Shout-outs in the Reveal. Be on the lookout!

I wonder how the colors relate to life expectancy and I wonder what factors contribute to life expectancy.

How does this relate to you and your community?

I think women in the U.S. are having less children and waiting until later in life to have children. I think people in the U.S. are living longer b/c of advancements in health care.

What do I notice? In the Americas the populations seems to mature quite significantly yet the overall size remains relatively the same. The Middle East and east Asia maintain a relatively young population whilst also growing in size. Lastly the African population seems to not only have grown tremendously but it bears the most youthful population out of all the continents.

What do I wonder? I'm curious as to why more developed nations display a trend of having a much more elderly population as opposed to less developed ones. And why other continents display relatively stable growth and Africa much more significant growth.

How does this relate to you and your community? Looking at South Africa, there does not seem to be any change of note so with regards to my immediate community it's hard to say, however looking at at all corners of the continent except the south , it would be possible for more people to have migrated to Africa due to the cheaper cost of living. And this assumption would make sense as a more elderly population would likely have more or earn more money than their youthful counterparts and thus could sustain their livelihood in Europe and Asia.
